instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont turn on
threads.message:
No visible liquid or corrosion damage, very clean. Only thing amiss was the badly cracked L7710 Inductor which I replaced.
charger lights up green to yellow, responds to SMC reset.

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 5.02v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> - 0v 
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> - 0v 
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - 0v 
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 12.62v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 3.36v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> - 0.08v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> - 0.08v 

I tried jumping the <CHIP>U8180</CHIP> to get to a PRAM reset but no change in readings and still wont power on.
Where should I look next?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont turn on
threads.message:
Real 85W charger?
Post <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> level.
Does it charge battery?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont turn on
threads.message:
Yes genuine 85W Magsafe2.

<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> - 0 V

I have it on the charger now, we'll see if it goes to green in a few hours
